facts.text: The last election to Taluka Panchayats took place in February 1968 and the Panchayats were constituted on February 28, 1968 with term due to expire on February 28, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The last election to Taluka Panchayats took place in February 1968 and the Panchayats were companystituted on February 28, 1968 Their term was due to expire on February 28, 1973.

facts.text: The five year term of the District Panchayats was due to expire on March 31, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, the five year term of the District Panchayats was due to expire on March 31 1973.

facts.text: By a Resolution dated April 12, 1973, the State Government appointed a high level Committee headed by Jhinabhai Darji.

anchor.surface_text: By a Resolution dated April 12, 1973, the State Government appointed a high level Committee headed by Jhinabhai Darji to suggest basic reforms in the Panchayati Raj set-up.

facts.text: State Government extended terms of Taluka Panchayats upto August 31, 1973 and District Panchayats upto September 30, 1973 on interim recommendation of the Committee.

anchor.surface_text: On the interim recommendation of this Committee the State Government extended the terms of Taluka Panchayats upto August 31, 1973 and those of Distirct Pan chayats upto September 30, 1973.

facts.text: Gujarat Amending Act 9 of 1973 came into force on April 23, 1973, abolishing indirect elections to Taluka Panchayats and providing for direct elections.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon,the Gujarat  Amending  Act 9 of 1973 was passed. It came into force on April 23, 1973. This Amending Act made far- reaching changes in the original Act.

facts.text: State Government by order dated June 21, 1973 extended term of Taluka Panchayats till August 31, 1973 and District Panchayats till September 30, 1973.

facts.text: Widespread disturbances broke out in the State of Gujarat in the first week of January, 1974.

anchor.surface_text: In the first week of January, 1974, widespread disturbances broke out in the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: On January 26, 1974, the Governor of Gujarat promulgated Ordinance 1 of 1974 substituting two years for one year in s.17(2).

facts.text: President enacted Gujarat Panchayats Amendment Act 8 of 1974 on March 31, 1974 inserting s.303A.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his powers under s. 3 of this Act, the President enacted Gujarat Panchayats  Amendment  Act 8 of 1974 which came into force on March 31, 1974.

issues.text: Did a situation arising out of disturbances exist in the State of Gujarat on the date of the impugned notification?

anchor.surface_text: Thus the question that companyld be objectively companysidered by the Court in this case was Did a situation arising out of disturbances exist in the State of Gujarat on the date of the impugned numberification ?

issues.text: Whether the satisfaction of the State Government that it is not expedient to hold elections is justiciable and whether there is a reasonable nexus between the satisfaction and the objective fact of disturbances

anchor.surface_text: Both these factors are open to judicial review. The satisfaction of the Government with regard to the existence of a situation by reason of the disturbances or in respect of number-possibility or inexpediency of holding elections is subjective and number open to judicial review,

issues.text: Whether the phrase 'to hold elections' in s.303A includes preliminary steps such as delimitation of constituencies and preparation of electoral rolls or is restricted to the actual conduct of elections

anchor.surface_text: if the language of a statute is susceptible of two constructions, the one which fulfils its object is to be preferred to the alternative which frustrates it. This canon is of particular significance while interpreting an emergency measure of the kind before us.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court held that election within the companytemplation of section 303A 1  is restricted to the process of the actual companyduct of the election, companymencing with the issue of the numberification calling the election and terminating with the declaration of the result of the election.

arguments.claim: Impugned notification invalid as condition precedent under s.303A not satisfied because 'holding elections' restricted to actual conduct from notification to result declaration, excluding preliminaries like delimitation and electoral rolls

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that election within the contemplation of section 303A 1  is restricted to the process of the actual conduct of the election, commencing with the issue of the notification calling the election and terminating with the declaration of the result of the election. In its view the delimitation of constituencies or wards, preparation of electoral rolls, and framing of rules for conducting elec- tions, being stages prior to the election, do number form part of the process. of holding election.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.303A requires only objective existence of disturbances situation and subjective satisfaction on expediency; no statutory fetter requiring preliminaries

arguments.claim: No condition precedent of completed preliminaries for s.303A; only objective condition is existence of disturbances situation; satisfaction on inexpediency not justiciable

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Phadke, learned Counsel for the appellant-State contends that since the satisfaction of the Government as to the inexpediency of holding elections was number a justiciable matter, the giving of a wide or narrow meaning to the phrase to hold elections in s. 303A would number affect the point at issue. The High Court, it is contended, erred in treating the completion of the preliminaries, such as compilation of electoral rolls and formation of constituencies, virtually as a condition precedent to the exercise of the power, though the only condition precedent laid down by the statute which could be tested by objective standards was the existence of the situation created by the disturbances.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: nchayats and district Panchayats while formulating the proposals of delimitation of the companystituencies. An Assistant Development Commissioner visi

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; confirmed two requirements only, wide interpretation fulfills emergency object

arguments.claim: High Court correct: preliminaries like delimitation anterior to 'hold elections'; s.303A presupposes machinery ready but process not started; stage not reached due to disturbances

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nanawati, learned Counsel for the respondents  whose arguments have been adopted by Mr. Bhandare, appearing for respondents 1 and 9 , submitted that the High Court was right in holding that the preliminaries such as delimitation of constituencies etc. belong to a stage anterior to the conduct of elections and therefore do number fall within the ambit of the phrase to hold elections. The point pressed into argument, is that s. 303A presupposed that the election machinery was ready and all the preliminary steps for holding the elections, such as compilation of the voters lists and formation of wards etc., had been completed but the process of election had number yet started when disturbances intervened.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: That weighed with the Government in deciding that it was number politic in the then prevailing companyditions to extend the terms of the panchayats w

arguments.court_reasoning: Purposive construction prefers wide meaning including preliminaries for emergency provision object

arguments.claim: State's own case via Ordinance 1 shows preliminaries needed substantial time; notification exercised for extraneous reason (terms expiring) not disturbances

anchor.surface_text: Learned Counsel for the respondents next contended that it has been the positive case of the State that the preliminaries to the holding of elections required substantial time and that was why ordinance 1 of 1974 promulgated on January 25, 1974 had conferred power on the State Government to extend the terms of District and Taluka Panchayats by one year more with effect from March 31, 1974 and February 25, 1974, respectively. With reference to the first preamble of the impugned notification, it is contended, that it shows that the power  1   1974  2 W. L R. 545  Ch. D.  was exercised number because of any situation arising out of the disturbances but for an extraneous reason, namely, that the terms of all Taluka and District Panchayats were expiring on the 31st March 1974.

arguments.court_reasoning: Preamble recites fact part of situation; dominant reason in second para linked to disturbances; efforts detailed in counter-affidavit

arguments.claim: Resort to drastic undemocratic s.303A instead of available s.17(2) extension exhibits malice in law
arguments.court_reasoning: s.17(2) and s.303A operate in different fields with different objects: continuity vs dissolution and officer administration in disturbances

arguments.claim: Process of holding elections initiated in August 1973 with delimitation proposals; efforts thwarted by disturbances

anchor.surface_text: Avers he I deny that no efforts were at all made to hold elections of the Taluka Panchayats or the District Panchayats before March 31, 1974. in fact the process of holding elections was initiated as early as in August 1973, when the Development Commissioner called for the proposals for the delimitation of constituencies from the Collectors. The Development Commissioner had also instructed Collectors to consult taluka Panchayats and district Panchayats while formulating the proposals of delimitation of the constituencies.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: companynter, the Joint Secretary has explained how the efforts made by the Government to hold the elections were thwarted by the supervention of the d

arguments.court_reasoning: Details furnish complete answer; disturbances prevented expediency

arguments.claim: Situation of disturbances existed on March 31, 1974, continuing from Jan-Feb into March with loss of life, property damage, agitation against panchayats

anchor.surface_text: The fact that there were serious disturbances throughout the State of Gujarat in January and in the first fortnight of March, 1974. has number been seriously disputed by the learned Counsel for the respondents. From the counter-affidavit filed on behalf of the State, it appears that these disturbances continued throughout March, 1974. Shri Satyendra Shah, Joint Secretary to Government of Gujarat has sworn that disturbances on a wide scale occurred in all parts of the State-both in the urban as well as in the rural areas, resulting in loss of human life and considerable damage to property.

arguments.claim: Situation by reason of disturbances subsists even after abatement as proximate effect; sufficient time needed to return to normalcy

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the disturbances had abated after the dissolution of the State Assembly on March 15, 1974, the abnormal situation in the State, which was the direct product of the disturbances. continued to exist throughout March 1974. Sufficient time was therefore, required for the situation to limp back to normalcy. It is to be noted that s. 303A 1 , speaks of the existence of a situation by reason of disturbances. The expression by reason of indicates that the disturbances and the situation must be proximately connected as cause and effect.

arguments.claim: s.303A has two requirements: (1) objective existence of disturbances situation, (2) govt subjective satisfaction it is not expedient to hold elections; first reviewable, second not if reasonable nexus

anchor.surface_text: An analysis of s.303A  1  would show that before a declaration referred to in that sub-section can be made, two requirements must be fulfilled  1  existence of a situation by reason of a disturbances in the whole or any part of the State  2  the satisfaction of the State Government relatable to such a situation, that it is number expedient to hold elections for the reconstitution of a panchayat on the expiry of its term. The first requirement is an objective fact and the second is an opinion or inference drawn from that fact.

arguments.claim: Phrase 'to hold elections' and 'expedient' to be construed widely/purposively to include preliminaries, fulfilling emergency object over narrow frustrating construction

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well-settled that if the language of a statute is susceptible of two constructions, the one which fulfils its object is to be preferred to the alternative which frustrates it. This canon is of particular significance while interpreting an emergency measure of the kind before us. ... In the provision under consideration the phrase to hold elections can be understood both in a wide and a narrow sense. Its wide connotation will include all steps such as the delimitation of constituencies, the compilation of electoral rolls etc.

arguments.claim: Reasonable nexus exists between govt satisfaction and objective disturbances facts; not colourable

anchor.surface_text: The first requirement, if disputed, must be established objectively as a condition precedent to the exercise of the power. The second is a matter of subjective satisfaction of the Government and is number justifiable. Once a reasonable nexus between such satisfaction and the facts constituting the first requirement is shown, the exercise of the power by the Government, number being colourable or motivated by extraneous considerations,is number open to judicial review.

arguments.claim: Agitation for panchayat dissolution continued till end March 1974, preventing functioning

anchor.surface_text: in a further affidavit it is stated that an agitation for dissolution of the Panchayats, whose normal terms of office had expired, continued even in the last days of March, 1974. An instance of Kutch Panchayat which on account of such agitation, was unable to assemble for the budget meeting at Bhui has been cited.

holdings.text: The Notification dated March 31, 1974 issued by the State Government is valid as the condition precedent to the exercise of the power under s. 303A is satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: The main question that arises in these two appeals direct against the common judgment, dated June 26, 1974 of the High Court of Gujarat, is, whether the Notification dated March 31, 1974  for short, the impugned notification  issued by the State Government is invalid on the ground that the condition precedent to the exercise of the power under s. 303A of the Gujarat Panchayats Act, 1961, for short, the Panchayats Act  is not satisfied.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Objective situation of disturbances existed throughout March 1974; subjective satisfaction had reasonable nexus; wide construction of 'hold elections' includes preliminaries; no statutory requirement for completed preliminaries; no mala fides.

holdings.text: A situation arising out of disturbances existed in the State of Gujarat on the date of the impugned notification.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the question that could be objectively considered by the Court in this case was Did a situation arising out of disturbances exist in the State of Gujarat on the date of the impugned notification ? The fact that there were serious disturbances throughout the State of Gujarat in January and in the first fortnight of March, 1974. has not been seriously disputed by the learned Counsel for the respondents.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed disturbances from January continued through March with loss of life, property damage, and agitation against panchayats; situation subsists post-abatement as proximate effect requiring time to normalize.

holdings.text: Before declaration under s.303A(1), two requirements: (1) objective existence of situation by reason of disturbances; (2) State Government's satisfaction (relatable to such situation) that it is not expedient to hold elections; first reviewable objectively, second subjective and non-justiciable if reasonable nexus shown and not colourable.

anchor.surface_text: An analysis of s.303A  1  would show that before a declaration referred to in that sub-section can be made, two requirements must be fulfilled  1  existence of a situation by reason of a disturbances in the whole or any part of the State  2  the satisfaction of the State Government relatable to such a situation, that it is not expedient to hold elections for the reconstitution of a panchayat on the expiry of its term.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of s.303A(1); distinction between objective fact and subjective opinion; nexus insulates from review unless colourable.

holdings.text: Phrase 'to hold elections' in s.303A construed widely to include preliminary steps like delimitation and electoral rolls, not restricted to actual conduct.

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well-settled that if the language of a statute is susceptible of two constructions, the one which fulfils its object is to be preferred to the alternative which frustrates it. This canon is of particular significance while interpreting an emergency measure of the kind before us. ... In the provision under consideration the phrase to hold elections can be understood both in a wide and a narrow sense.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious/purposive construction for emergency provision; wide amplitude fulfills object of tiding over crisis over narrow frustrating interpretation.

holdings.text: No condition precedent requiring completion of preliminaries like delimitation or electoral rolls before exercising power under s.303A.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, it is contended, erred in treating the completion of the preliminaries, such as compilation of electoral rolls and formation of constituencies, virtually as a condition precedent to the exercise of the power, though the only condition precedent laid down by the statute which could be tested by objective standards was the existence of the situation created by the disturbances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statute imposes no such fetter; only objective condition is disturbances situation; wide meaning of 'hold elections'.

holdings.text: Resort to s.303A instead of s.17(2) does not exhibit mala fides or malice; provisions operate in different fields with distinct objects.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.17(2) for continuity via extension; s.303A for dissolution and officer administration in disturbances; choice not malicious given circumstances.

holdings.text: Reasonable nexus exists between government's satisfaction of inexpediency and objective facts of disturbances; exercise of power not colourable.

anchor.surface_text: Once a reasonable nexus between such satisfaction and the facts constituting the first requirement is shown, the exercise of the power by the Government, not being colourable or motivated by extraneous considerations,is not open to judicial review.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Counter-affidavit details link efforts to hold elections thwarted by ongoing disturbances and agitation.

holdings.text: The situation under s.303A(1) need not be co-terminous with disturbances but sufficient if immediate outcome and subsisting.

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the disturbances had abated after the dissolution of the State Assembly on March 15, 1974, the abnormal situation in the State, which was the direct product of the disturbances. continued to exist throughout March 1974.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual: 'by reason of' indicates proximate cause-effect; time needed post-abatement to normalize.

holdings.text: Government should take prompt measures to hold elections expeditiously and not use judgment to postpone indefinitely.

anchor.surface_text: We hope that the Government will take prompt measures to hold there elections expeditiously and will not use this judgment as an excuse to postpone the elections indefinitely.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exhortation in democratic context; non-binding hope.

anchor.surface_text: The main question that arises in these two appeals direct against the common judgment, dated June 26, 1974 of the High Court of Gujarat, is, whether the Notification dated March 31, 1974  for short, the impugned notification  issued by the State Government is invalid on the ground that the condition precedent to the exercise of the power under s. 303A of the Gujarat Panchayats Act, 1961, for short, the Panchayats Act  is not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the question that could be objectively considered by the Court in this case was Did a situation arising out of disturbances exist in the State of Gujarat on the date of the impugned notification ? The fact that there were serious disturbances throughout the State of Gujarat in January and in the first fortnight of March, 1974. has not been seriously disputed by the learned Counsel for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: An analysis of s.303A  1  would show that before a declaration referred to in that sub-section can be made, two requirements must be fulfilled  1  existence of a situation by reason of a disturbances in the whole or any part of the State  2  the satisfaction of the State Government relatable to such a situation, that it is not expedient to hold elections for the reconstitution of a panchayat on the expiry of its term.

edges.explanation: Holding directly addresses and resolves the issue of scope of 'to hold elections' via wide construction

anchor.surface_text: Now it is well-settled that if the language of a statute is susceptible of two constructions, the one which fulfils its object is to be preferred to the alternative which frustrates it. This canon is of particular significance while interpreting an emergency measure of the kind before us. ... In the provision under consideration the phrase to hold elections can be understood both in a wide and a narrow sense.

The High Court, it is contended, erred in treating the completion of the preliminaries, such as compilation of electoral rolls and formation of constituencies, virtually as a condition precedent to the exercise of the power, though the only condition precedent laid down by the statute which could be tested by objective standards was the existence of the situation created by the disturbances.
